message: I'm not really trying to create an argument about GUI vs CLI... I guess if a GUI editor has great SSH/SCP/SFTP/FTP support, I'd use it and do away with editing directly on the server entirely.
I've been using nano to edit files over ssh almost exclusively and I know its a bad habit, but I havent quit yet.
Emacs has built-in SSH support with tramp, it's definitely worth a try.

Vim is my main editor, specifically MacVim, but it doesn't matter which Vim you use.  It's not easy to learn, but it's worth the month to get really productive. Textmate was nice when I used it 3 years ago, but it's dying on the vine. Now that I'm use to modes, I won't go back.

MacVim is a great way to get into vim, since you can still "cheat" and use the scrollwheel and mouse selection. Even though I am pretty good at vim now, I still use them. Vim takes a while to get all set up, but you can get by for starters with just NERDTree and maybe PeepOpen.
